Comments_List: Around 2 hours on readings, 15 hours when we had a policy brief due, which there are 2 of (one alone and one with a group). no exams!
3-5 for readings
2 normally.  15-20 during project season.
3 when assignments were not due; 7-10 when assignments were due.
6 hours of reading, a lot of work (reading and writing) when assignments are due. Definitely worthwhile doing the reading to get the most out of the class.
Spent a few hours each week for regular readings and more if there was an assignment due.
When assignments are due: 20. When no assignments are due: 0.
0 - because I stopped doing the readings. Just way too many, especially as an AP student taking 6 classes.
15-20 hours
10-15 hours
Loved it! Sometimes a little US heavy because I'm interested in global health, but for the most part I was able to apply concepts nationally.
Excellent course. I learned so much about the politics of health care. The policy brief we had to write was a great experience.

Strengths are that this course requires you to think about politics and why policies might not pass or have issues with public support or feasibility etc. It is definitely a different lens to view health policy through. Weaknesses are that the lecture can get pretty dry and hard to follow along since there is no lecture slides.

Great course to take for those who are interested in learning about health politics and how the structure of U.S. government affects policy/policy decisions. I personally didn't like how many readings there were, but it is a small critique given how informative the course was and how much I enjoyed taking the class.
great information.

Strengths: clearly Professor Schlessinger, with nothing but a white-board and a marker, can hold an audience for 2 hours. 

Weaknesses: the volume and age of readings

Strengths:
- Very unique approach to the world of health policy, as other policy courses at YSPH and elsewhere seem to focus on economics/history
- Thought provoking topics and questions raised
- Opportunities to earn from peers
- Mark's teaching style and mentorship -- very accessible and engaging

Weaknesses:
- Peers oftentimes unprepared when attending class, making for discussion that could be richer
- Can see students who hold more right-leaning ideologies feeling defensive/unwelcome

Strength: breaks down political theories as they apply to health policy in an easy-to-understand way
Weakness: some tedious very theoretical topics.
Very good course

This was a great course that strengthened students' understanding of the political, ideological, and structural factors that shape US health policy. I enjoyed that this course explored these topics within the framework of timely policy issues including LTC, the ACA, and other major policy movements. After taking this course, I have a much better understanding of the elements that shape US health policy.

My only suggestion to improve this course is to provide the weekly handout  in a digital copy to reduce paper usage.

Uses the literature to explore the relationships between government, political forces, and public opinion with respect to health policy. Great discussions based around the literature

How could it be improved: Sometimes I felt a little 'led', like there was a right answer to some of the questions posed by Prof. (based on the literature). It would be nice if there was time to discuss our own thoughts around the topics. 

The group project at the end of the semester just about broke me, I ended up having to write someone else's section at the 11th hour, when I had other coursework and exams to study for. There was too much reading for the final assignment, which wasn't completely necessary to complete the assignment.

Absolutely loved this course! It opened my eyes to a new way of thinking about politics and policy-making in healthcare. The readings and lecture were very well intertwined and I really enjoyed writing the policy papers.

This is a fantastic class if you are willing to put in the work and come prepared to class. Even though there were many students in the class, it was still very much a discussion-based course where students could make comments, ask questions, and debate aspects of health policy.
Fantastic! Great way to expand on what we learned in our intro to health policy class last semester. Very engaging topic and interesting material.

Its a great show of history and balance of how government and health combined into what/where we are today.  Professor is excellent. 
The one thing I would do differently is, since many people are graduating and this is one of the last courses they take.  Push the last policy paper assignment to a few weeks earlier in the semester, otherwise it really lingers on an on, and makes the last few weeks of the semester a bit tougher with competing exams.

I really didnt feel like I learned much. It might because I have a pretty solid poli-Sci background, but nothing seemed like new information to me. I also feel like no one did the readings consistently, and I would recommend reducing both assignments by about 5 pages and introducing assignments that are smaller and force people to do the readings weekly. Both written assignments were topically interesting, learned a lot from writhing both of them.

My biggest problem with this class was the group assignment. Why. Why. Why make a 15 page paper a group assignment. I was  stuck with a terrible group, had to rewrite everything, and the people in my group just didnt care. Why should I be forced to share my grade with them? If you must keep this as a group assignments, why not let people choose their group? Yes we will self select into groups that have more similar experiences as us but that isnt necessarily a bad thing. Let the people who dont care stick  together and the people who actually want to learn and work together. Also I dont see the point in working in a group for this, since we were all just answering different sections.

Absolutely amazing course! This course reminds me of why I wanted to pursue policy to begin with. I really enjoyed the breadth of material that the class covered because I had not thought about some of those topics in a health context specifically, like how this is the only course that touches on therapeutic jurisprudence. I thought that both policy briefs were also really helpful in allowing me to apply what I learned to explain concepts: I think this was definitely a more effective way of engaging with the material rather than just taking an exam. Overall, one of my favorite classes I've taken!
Overall the course is great but the final policy brief was too comprehensive to cover in just one essay especially to be structured as a group project.
Favorite class.
Professor Schlesinger should cold call on students to make sure they are engaged and did the readings.

Liked the structure of the course with just the two assignments. Although felt the assignments just asked for way too much to really go into great detail on with the word limit. Would rather have a more focused question to answer. Class was engaging and generally interesting.
This course was very interesting, but it was often difficult to follow along with the class due to the lecture-hall environment without a visual/presentation aid.
Not engaging

Very good course, well positioned in the syllabus. I do wonder if the mix of breadth and depth could trade-off too much in terms of generating deeper policy insights but this is only a small complaint as this is clearly a well refined course.
I absolutely loved this course.
Course was fine but there was a substantial amount of reading and content. Final project was on a boring topic that would have been more interesting if there more options to choose from
Consider allowing students to pick their own groups for the final project.

This is one of my favorite courses at Yale.  While the reading list is long, I learned the most from dedicated reading effort.  Topics in health care policy, politics and governance are well covered and with a balanced view.  Amazing learning material!

Strengths: interesting content and covered a broad range of contemporary issues in health policy 

Weaknesses: readings could have been better labeled on canvas which would have made them easier to find during class
-taking this class should not be mandatory for all health policy students. If this class was a seminar, more people who want to the take the class would be there and would participate.
-participation grades were not clear as to how they would be graded
-1st paper should not be out of 10 if someone with an MPP and 5 years of experience would get a 9.5
-course should have several small policy briefs with an emphasis on how to format and construct them instead of large research papers covering different topics

Strengths: Provides questions and frameworks to be able to critically assess policymaking in the U.S. moving forward: whereas other HPM courses provided groundwork and background information for understanding why the U.S. healthcare system is the way it is in the present, I feel that this class helped me to think about how the healthcare system may evolve in the future. 
Weaknesses: This course may be a bit hard to follow for people who do not have prior knowledge about the U.S. healthcare system and public assistance programs - for those who come in without having taken one of the introductory HPM courses, it might be good to provide informational readings on these topics so that students can more easily apply the political science frameworks presented throughout the semester.
Very interesting.
the lectures are a bit disorganized and rambling tends to occur.  I wish there were lecture slides i could reference afterwards.

Overall this was a phenomenal course. I greatly enjoyed Professor Schlesinger's teaching style of not using power points and simply orating and using the chalkboard. It was also nice to get handouts for each class with figures we could refer to. 

The only thing I would tweak about this course is maybe having more updated figurers for the points discussed in class. Many of them seem to be 10-20 years old, and they still might be valid, but newer data would be better.
The final group project leaves room for great variability and unnecessary stress. It should be an individual project or an exam.

Great intro course about HOW to get involved in health politics, rather than recapping existing policies. I like that he goes over basic concepts in political science but teaches it through the specific lens of recent healthcare policy.
This course was fantastic. It really took us through the entire political and legislative process that's behind every health policy decision.

Very good and thoughtful exposure to the subject matter.
Way too much reading material. Impossible to cover everything

Amazing. Hands-down one of my favourite professors at YSPH. Kind, approachable and really cares about the progression of our learning. Took a lot of time to hand-pick our groups for the group project, always available to meet outside of class to chat. Works really closely with the TF, which is very key.
Professor Schlesinger is an excellent professor. Lecturing for two hours isn't easy but he was able to hold my attention the entire time.
Mark is a great lecturer. I wish he would provide slides to follow along better. He has an outline on the board but it can get hard to follow and there are lots of tangents.

Prof Schlesinger is very knowledgeable and passionate about the topic. Lectures are engaging, especially considering there aren't powerpoint slides for the lectures. I don't think powerpoint slides are necessary for his lectures, but it could be helpful to have one ppt slide per day that lists the topics for the day (rather than have it be written on the board)
wealth of knowledge... love mark!

Incredible teacher and it was really refreshing to not have just PowerPoint slides, but rather true dissemination of subject mastery. 

I don't think the paper hand-outs are necessary, just put them on Canvas, save the trees!

Left-biased in a distracting way.  Would have appreciated hearing real arguments from a conservative viewpoint instead of dismissing them all as uneducated opinions. Hard to know where you stand in the class, because project averages aren't published, and you don't get any class feedback until near the very end of the semester.  Canvas folders and labeling could be improved.

Appreciate his amazingly vast knowledge of the topics, and his ability to convey the material in a clear and easy-to-follow way.
Very positive

Mark is a FANTASTIC professor. He is extremely enthusiastic, knowledgeable, and kind. I truly appreciated taking this course with him as the instructor. 

The only suggestion I have for improvement is timeliness in grading the first assignment. I understand that he was grading about 60 15-page policy memos, so I don't necessarily have any suggestions for improving the timeliness of grading, but if possible, it would have been helpful to get the midterm grades back before the end of the semester (preferably within a few weeks of the deadline).

Strengths: Approachable, encourages critical thinking
Weaknesses: None
Dr. Schlesinger is a wonderful lecturer who is very experienced with the material and is able to make this very complicated material interesting and easy to understand.

Professor Schlesinger isn't everyone's cup of tea, but I really appreciate his teaching style. It is clear that he wants to make us think and chew over some very big questions in health policy. He balances lecturing and conversation very well, and encourages students to think out loud rather than necessarily wait until they have the perfectly-crafted response.
Mark is wonderful! Incredibly passionate about what he does and I love that he takes a discussion-type tone during class: it is engaging.
Professor Schlesinger is excellent.  Incredible insight.
Knowledgeable and very sweet man.

Mark is AMAZING: I think that he is always very clear when teaching and the lecture never feels like it is going on for 2 hours. Mark is really great at integrating everything together and relating the overall topics to specific examples in healthcare. I would say the only downside was how long it took to grade the policy briefs, but I also understand since they were very long and there were so many. Overall, Mark is an amazing professor and I learned so much from him! Excited for the capstone next year!
Mark is a great lecturer

Truly fantastic.  Extremely knowledgeable in so many different domains.  Incredibly insightful in explaining structural factors that contributed to the development of our current health policy landscape and why policy makers need to be sensitive to those structures if they want to succeed in meaningful health reform.

Really enjoyed Prof Schlesinger's class. He clearly dedicates a lot of time and effort into the class. Has an unbelievable command of the literature, to the point where it seems like every single article is memorized in a library in his head. Lectures were engaging and I generally looked forward to the class.
Dr. Schelsinger is a very dynamic instructor who made the content very interesting.
Good lecturer
very engaging and helpful. Provided excellent feedback on assignments
Excellent, maybe at times could've pushed beyond a recapitulation of the readings but again, a relatively small complaint

I really look up to Mark. Consistently impressed that he walks into class, writes 8 things on the board, then lectures from memory/intelligence, and ties everything together nicely. 

This class makes you think about things in politics and governance that probably weren't on your radar but are now somehow obviously crucial to health care policy and reform. 

Mark is always willing to chat about readings/coursework/YSPH/policy/anything.
Mark is great, I really enjoyed his instruction

Professor Schlesinger is amazing!  He promotes wonderful classroom discussions with thought provoking questions.  The material is organized and balanced.  Reading list is top notch.  While he stated that we don't have to read everything, I found that my learning was greatly enhanced by reading all the papers.  Professor Schlesinger is an inspiration for students who are interested in health policy and politics.

Very knowledgeable about course material!

Only improvement would be to encourage more participation if participation is such a substantial percentage of the grade.

One of the best lecturers I've had at YSPH! There was a huge breadth of information covered each lecture, but he presented material in an organized fashion that made it easy to follow and extract key takeaways.
Super insightful.
Great and very knowledgeable
Fantastic. Would not change anything.

Generally great instructor. He is thoughtful, coherent, and clearly plans out his lectures. He encourages student participation in a constructive way, critiquing answers that need strengthening and pushing students in the class. I do have two small complaints:
1) he often ends lecture with food for thought questions for the class, but we never revisit to discuss them, which I found frustrating
2) sometimes, he presents somewhat subjective evidence as hard evidence of his points, and I'm not always convinced. However, there isn't always time or space in class to debate him when he does this. Would like some way to be able to discuss without derailing the whole class.

Our professor was fantastic! I actually love that he didn't use powerpoints. He mainly lectured and wrote outlines on the board, referring to what topic we were touching upon at the moment. Very knowledgable. Wry sense of humor. Always friendly, enjoyable, and constantly made us think on our toes!

Excellent mastery of material
Engaging lectures
Awesome, definitely take it if you're looking to learn more about the intersection of political sciences and health.
Highly recommend it to anyone who wants to learn more about health politics.

I would recommend if you have time!! It's a great course and you learn a lot of practical skills by writing policy briefs and recommendations for real-world problems. However, the assignments can get pretty heavy.

Again, a great course to take for those who are interested in learning about health politics and how the structure of U.S. government affects policy/policy decisions. As someone with little policy/politics experience taking the course, there is really so much to learn. I would definitely recommend the course to any student interested in healthcare, not just policy students.
great healthcare policy class.

This is a hardcore policy course, so if you're indifferent to government and policy, it's going to be tough. Fortunately, Professor Schlessinger is so well versed on the topic and raises great questions during class. But be forewarned, it's A LOT of reading and some of it is outdated and just so lengthy and academic. Then if you refer to a source outside of the readings, they don't like that. It's required for policy, so not really a choice but to recommend. Amazing teacher, modernize and reduce some of the auxiliary readings.

Definitely would recommend, especially if students are interested in talking about the actual policymaking/politics of health policy, such as what makes a policy more likely to pass, what went on behind closed doors that led to a policy failing, etc. Very unique approach to health policy, and definitely one of the courses at YSPH that pushed my level of critical thinking supplemented by evidence.
summarizes how political science influences health policy.  course was just okay overall.
Great

I would recommend this course to anyone interested in understanding the political facets that shape US healthcare decisions. 

This course provides a background in the political, ideological, and structural factors that shape US health policy, studied through the framework of timely policy issues including LTC, the ACA, and other major policy movements.
Recommend for all health policy students.
Definitely would recommend taking this course! It is great for anyone interested in health policy or learning about barriers to policy-making in general.

This is a great course if you want to read and learn a lot. The course load is fairly heavy, but it is very worth it. If you are itching for a class that offers more participation than most in YSPH, TAKE THIS CLASS. It's a very thoughtful, well-crafted course through and through.
Great class to really dive into health policy and governance! Highly recommend.
This is a must take for anyone in the health profession including clinicians and administrators.
Its a requirement. I wouldnt take this if you dont have to though. Health Econ is much more interesting with much less work.

To summarize this course, I would say that this course goes further into how the US has constructed its political system and how that relates to health policy. It takes EPH 510 a few steps further and looks at not only what is happening but why it is happening. I would 100% recommend this to policy and non-policy students alike because it is an amazing course and I think it teaches concepts relevant for every public health student moving forward.

It's an important course in learning more about feasibility and sustainability of US healthcare policy. It's a core course for policy students but for anyone who wants to learn how to think more critically about health policy, I highly recommend.
Take it.  The papers are difficult but they help synthesize a lot of knowledge in ways that a final exam or routine assignments cannot.

Compulsory if in the policy track. One of the better Profs at Yale. Covers new content in comparison to some other spring courses which I felt re-hashed concepts that were covered in the fall. Would recommend.
I would definitely recommend this course for a student who wants to know more about the intricacies of health policy and policymaking.
I recommend this course to everyone interested in health policy - not just the policy students!

This is an interesting course on the politics of healthcare and has some more varied content than other courses of similar subject matter. However, there is much more reading that I found necessary and the projects are relatively narrow in terms of your ability to respond

You have to work hard to learn the material.  I have been working in the US health care system for over 20 years.  And finally through this course, I learned some basics of how the health care systems work in the US and in the world.  This course is a must-have!

Highly recommended for people interested in policymaking as it relates to the U.S. healthcare system, across the public and private sector - if your interest tends toward global health, not sure how much you'd glean from this course.
Yes.
Great course with great content taught by someone who really understands this material. Would highly recommend. A lot of reading, but writing assignments will actually be useful for my future.

This course is pretty much exactly what you'd expect, and it's fantastic. You're going to be made to think on your toes during the class. There is a heavy emphasis on writing. 2 assignments. No exams. I personally like this setup, but it's not for everyone. Overall, the experience was amazing.

Great learning opportunity but challenging near impossible to cover all reading assignments in a timely manner
Still possible to learn/do well by performing well on the 2 writeups
